page.title: 07THE BUTTER CROSS NR.ALVELEY
page.content: Near Alveley there is a rough stone pillar about 2 metres high.The top is circular in shape.Inside the circle there is a design in the shape of a cross with triangles at each end of the cross.The pillar is fixed into a round base made of the same kind of sandstone.There are some engravings on the pillar and they include the initials WWT.It is known as the Butter Cross and it has a very interesting history.It is said that in the 17th Century the people in Bridgnorth caught the Great Plague.Alveley,in those days,sold butter to Bridgnorth.To avoid catching the plague the Alveley farmers left their butter at the cross and walked away while the Bridgnorth people collected it and left their money in bowls of disinfectant.So the Butter Cross saved the people of Alveley from the plague.
